articles.title: Science 101: Urban Heat Island
articles.author: Jim Kosek
articles.summary: The urban heat island effect occurs when urban areas experience higher temperatures than surrounding rural areas. It's due to the physical makeup of cities as well as human activity. Chicago has Lake Michigan that helps temper high heat, but the wind isn't always off the lake. Even in central Illinois, city temperatures will run higher than smaller towns.

articles.title: London heat wave falls short of record, triggers decade-high power demand
articles.author: Jacob Reid
articles.summary: This week's heat wave brought London temperatures of 33.7 C on Monday, the highest daily reading since August 2021. Monday's high fell short of the local high-heat mark for the date, June 23, which was set 102 years ago with temperatures of 36.1 C.

articles.title: 'Invisible peril' heatwaves can kill 500,000 people yearly
articles.author: bne Intelli News
articles.summary: Up to 500,000 people die annually from extreme heat, surpassing the toll of natural disasters such as earthquakes, hurricanes and floods combined. July 2024 saw the planet's warmest three-day stretch ever recorded. Since the 1960s, these events have nearly tripled in the United States, with each now reaching higher peak temperatures and extending about one day longer on average. In the UK, the current summer heat in England has risen to between 2°C and 4°C warmer than similar events in past decades. The UK experienced its first-ever 40°C temperature in 2022.

articles.title: New ‘zero-tolerance' policy for construction parking and traffic disruptions passed by Port Moody council
articles.author: Patrick Penner
articles.summary: Construction is seen at the corner of Austin Avenue and Nelson street on Sept. 15, 2022. Heat Warning from TUE 3:33 PM EDT until WED 6:00 AM EDT until the end of the construction. The website is the Peterborough Examiner.

articles.title: Toronto Sees Record Temperatures as Extreme Heat Settles Over Canada
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Sweltering temperatures in Toronto have prompted health alerts and pool closures. Students are warned to expect 'uncomfortable conditions' because of the heat. The temperature has not been this high in Toronto in nearly a decade and it's felt this hot in almost a decade.

articles.title: Park where Niagara Region Chair Jim Bradley played as a child renamed in his honour
articles.author: Allan Benner
articles.summary: Grantham Avenue Park is being renamed for longtime St. Catharines politician Jim Bradley. Heat Warning from TUE 3:33 PM EDT until WED 6:00 AM EDT until Wednesday 6 a.m. PM EDT. For more information, go to: www.stcatharinesstandard.com.

articles.title: S&P cuts growth forecast amid tariff uncertainty
articles.author: Brett Rowland
articles.summary: Partly cloudy this evening with more clouds for overnight. Low 73F. Winds will be light and variable. In the evening, the sky will be partly cloudy. The forecast is for a cloudy sky with some partial cloudy conditions.  In the morning, the skies will be mostly sunny.

articles.title: Special Editorial: Advancements and Innovations in Carbon Capture,
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: As of 2023, atmospheric CO2 levels have reached over 420 parts per million. The focus on carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS) has gained considerable momentum. Geological formations possess an impressive storage capacity that can contain more carbon than has been emitted by human activities since the dawn of the Industrial Revolution. The journey toward widespread adoption of CCUS is fraught with challenges.

articles.title: Ontario heat wave hit record temperatures on Monday in these communities
articles.author: Metroland Staff
articles.summary: The ongoing heat wave is breaking temperature records across southern Ontario. 20 southern Ontario communities experienced the warmest June 22 on record on Sunday. Environment Canada has announced more communities experienced record temperatures yesterday. The hottest June 23 on record was on Monday, according to Environment Canada.

articles.title: Ontario heat wave hit record temperatures on Monday in these communities
articles.author: Metroland Staff
articles.summary: It was the hottest June 23 on record in southern Ontario, according to the Canadian Meteorological Agency. Toronto, Ottawa, Halton, Durham, Niagara, Simcoe, Muskoka, Peterborough, and elsewhere experienced the hottest day on record on June 23.

articles.title: Indigenous community withdraws from flag raising over beef with St. Catharines
articles.author: Matthew P. Barker
articles.summary: Heat Warning from TUE 3:33 PM EDT until WED 6:00 AM EDT. Niagara Regional Native Centre in Niagara-on-the-Lake is in the weather warning area. It's expected to be warm and muggy in the region.

articles.title: Sudden swells damage boats on Karwar Beach
articles.summary: There was a sudden rise in the Arabian Sea's water level on Tuesday, which caused damage to several fishing boats anchored along Karwar Beach. The tides receded by the afternoon, easing the situation. The fishermen stayed away from venturing into the sea on both Monday and Tuesday following the Meteorological Department's warning of rough conditions and high tides.

articles.title: 'Alligator Alcatraz': Florida building migrant detention centre in Everglades
articles.author: Ali Abbas Ahmadi
articles.summary: Florida is planning to build a migrant detention centre in Everglades. It will be funded "in large part" by the Federal Emergency Management Agency's shelter and services programme, which was previously used to provide accommodation and other aid for undocumented migrants. It comes as Trump tries to deliver on a campaign pledge to ramp up deportations of illegal migrants.

articles.title: Grenada renews disaster risk insurance with CCRIF SPC
articles.author: Now Grenada
articles.summary: The Government of Grenada renewed its disaster risk insurance coverage with the Caribbean Catastrophe Risk Insurance Facility Segregated Portfolio Company for the 2025/26 policy year. A total of US$1,827,718 plus applicable fees has been paid to secure continued protection against a range of natural hazards. Grenada has been a member of CCRIF SPC since 2007.

articles.title: The Two-Decade Decline of Florida's Citrus Industry
articles.author: Todd Crawford
articles.summary: Citrus industry in Florida has been in decline for the past two decades due to a variety of factors. The main one is citrus greening, a lethal disease that kills trees within years of being infected. Other factors are environmental factors, such as drought and extreme weather, and intensive agricultural practices. Alico Inc. announced it would be shutting down operations after this growing season due to the combination of hurricane impacts.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Response to Glacier Retreat Paper in Science', by Gregory Wrightstone
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: Gregory Wrightstone wrote a response to a paper in the Journal Science on the future increase of glacial retreat. He points out that the current warming period began in the early 1700s and the Earth has been warming in fits and starts since then. Glacial history confirms that the bulk of the retreat since the end of the Little Ice Age occurred during a period of very low levels of carbon dioxide.

articles.title: Time to tackle the scourge of Scotland's seagulls...before somebody is killed
articles.author: Douglas Ross
articles.summary: Gulls pose a serious risk of injury and death to the elderly, the vulnerable and young children. People are sick and tired of the failure of the government to act to deal with the problem. NatureScot stopped issuing licences for the control of gulls altogether last year.

articles.title: Loire Valley châteaux under threat, warns the Climate Action Network in its latest report
articles.author: James Vasina
articles.summary: France is experiencing its first heatwave of the year. 4,000 law enforcement officers are deployed in France. Napoleon's iconic bicorne hat and personal treasures are expected to fetch millions in Paris. Israel is furious as France shuts weapon booths at Paris Airshow.

articles.title: Climate crisis a major threat for makhana farmers: Report
articles.author: Rakesh Roshan
articles.summary: Cooperative minister Prem Kumar has released a report titled 'Climate change and makhana farmers of Bihar' on Tuesday. Makhana is a water-based crop that requires ideal temperature of 20-35°C, humidity levels of 50-90%, and 1,000-2,500mm of annual rainfall. In 2024 alone, 40 rivers across Bihar dried up by March due to rising temperatures.

articles.title: 500 Bird Species Face Extinction Within 100 Years Due to Climate Change
articles.author: IANS
articles.summary: More than 500 bird species are likely to be wiped out from the face of the Earth in the next 100 years. The bare-necked umbrellabird, the helmeted hornbill and the yellow-bellied sunbird-asity are the most vulnerable. The extinction of these birds would greatly reduce the variety of bird shapes and sizes worldwide.

articles.title: A Climate of Tyranny: Weaponizing 'Mother Earth' for Global Economic & Political Control
articles.author: Alex Newman
articles.summary: The globalist agenda for world domination is inseparable from the pseudo-environmentalism that has found its most alarmist and dangerous expression in the 'climate' narrative. The Club of Rome has been central to the effort to use concerns about the environment to pursue what they euphemistically refer to as 'global governance'. The idea that CO 2 is 'pollution' is absurd. Peer-reviewed scientific literature continues to debunk the notion that human CO 2 emissions produce dangerous warming.

articles.title: Ancient carbon ‘burps' caused ocean oxygen crashes — and we're repeating the mistake
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Earth experienced powerful bursts of carbon dioxide 300 million years ago. The carbon dioxide from natural sources triggered dramatic drops in ocean oxygen levels. These ancient "carbon burps" led to dangerous periods for Earth's oceans and the planet. The current carbon dioxide levels are higher than in the past.

articles.title: Earth's Energy Imbalance Is Reaching Record Highs
articles.author: Atta Ur Rehman
articles.summary: Earth's energy imbalance is at record highs. It's causing storms, heatwaves and wild weather like we've never seen. Understanding this imbalance isn't just interesting, it's urgent for people passionate about our blue planet. Let's dive deep into what's happening and how it's reshaping our climate story right now.

articles.title: Tuesday Weather - Trade winds, spotty trade showers, minor coastal flooding
articles.author: Carly Yoshida
articles.summary: There are more clouds and scattered showers moving in with the trades. Small Craft Advisory is in effect until 6 PM HST today for several coastal zones, including Maʻalaea Bay and channels near the Big Island. A south swell will peak later today or tonight, bringing higher surf to south-facing shores.

articles.title: What Ancient Ice Sheets Can Tell Us About Future Sea Level Rise
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Beach cliffs on the Cornish coast show the history of climate and sea level rise. Scientists are trying to determine how quickly sea level is going to rise in the future. They suspect the rise is caused by the retreat of ice from Antarctica, rather than the ice from Greenland. Ed Gasson is involved in an international drilling project that aims to solve the mystery.

articles.title: Harbor Property Management in San Pedro Launches Comprehensive Emergency Preparedness Plan for Coastal Properties
articles.author: Get News
articles.summary: Harbor Property Management - San Pedro has rolled out a comprehensive emergency preparedness plan tailored for coastal properties in California as climate change leads to rising risks from natural disasters. It is due to be implemented on June 24, 2025, in Rancho Palos Verdes, California.

articles.title: Study Finds Declining Cloud Cover Behind Recent Warming Trend
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: The shortwave effect of clouds is the 'dominant term of the recent increase in absorbed solar radiation' explaining the 2001-2024 warming. Satellite observations indicate there was a 0.45 W/m² per decade per decade increase in solar radiation reaching the Earth's surface from 2001 to 2024. Declining cloud cover was the main reason for this.

articles.title: Study warns 500 bird species face extinction within 100 years
articles.summary: More than 500 bird species face extinction within 100 years, according to new research from the University of Reading. The number is three times higher than all bird extinctions recorded over the last 500 years since the year 1500. Even with complete protection from human-caused threats, 250 bird species could die out within the next century.

articles.title: Human-activity continues to lead cause of wildfires in B.C.
articles.author: John Arendt
articles.summary: Since April 1, British Columbia has had 437 wildfires, burning 649,936 hectares. 148 of the wildfires have been caused by lightning strikes, 275 by human activity and 12 are of undetermined cause. Extreme drought conditions have been observed in much of the province. Campfires are still allowed in most of B.C. as of June 24, but restrictions are in place in some areas.

articles.title: Temperature in New York City reaches 100 degrees as eastern US swelters under extreme heat wave
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: A shirtless man crossed the Brooklyn Bridge during a heatwave on Tuesday, June 24, 2025, in New York. The Toronto Star has published a photo of the man. The photo is of a flag with a flag sponsored by Toronto Star. The flag is of the flag wire.

articles.title: At least 120 children abducted in Mozambique, rights group says
articles.author: Gavin Blackburn
articles.summary: At least 120 children have been kidnapped by jihadist insurgents in northern Mozambique in recent days. Human Rights Watch warns of a rise in abductions in the country's troubled Cabo Delgado province. The children are reportedly being used by a group linked to the so-called Islamic State to transport looted goods, perform forced labour and in some cases serve as child soldiers. The government forces have struggled to contain the violence.

articles.title: Camp educates students on coastal ecology in West Haven despite heat wave
articles.author: Kent Pierce
articles.summary: This is the first heat wave of the year. The West Haven Center for Coastal Ecology, or 'eco-camp', has been educating young people in West Haven for more than 30 years. This year, the camp is revamping the curriculum to talk about the seasons and climate change.

articles.title: Ocean crisis demands a new kind of science, say researchers
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: The ocean is under growing stress from overfishing, warming, pollution, acidification, deoxygenation and extreme climate events. Ocean scientists have documented these changes in detail and have been sounding the alarm for decades, but meaningful political action is still lagging. Scientists need to rethink their role as scientists and become active participants in change. They need to build stronger alliances with civil society, government and Indigenous and local communities. Governments and institutions need to provide more support to make deeper engagement possible.

articles.title: Exercising or playing sports in extreme heat can be dangerous
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Extreme heat makes it hard for your body to cool down. Your brain tries to keep your body within a degree or two of 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit (37 degrees Celsius) by triggering sweat. When sweat dries, it carries away heat from your body's surface.

articles.title: Cuts to NOAA funding could imperil weather forecasts, endanger lives
articles.author: Dinah Voyles Pulver
articles.summary: The White House proposed cutting NOAA's budget by 40% and eliminating all funding for the Office of Atmospheric Research. The research program underpins NOAA's work and scientific advances. The only office under the NOAA umbrella slated to see an increase is the National Weather Service, which could see a $71 million increase to its direct program budget.

articles.title: Kent Cultural Alliance hosts ‘CLIMATE' artist residency this summer
articles.author: H Combs
articles.summary: Evan Kassof and Marty Two Bulls Jr. will join the SFW Resident Artist Program for a six-week community-based residency on climate change in Kent County and the surrounding area. They will study and create works that shed light on the climate crisis in the area.

articles.title: New soil DNA monitoring technique provides data for better urban wildlife planning
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: There are more than half the world's people living in cities. Urban land cover is expected to increase by about 1.2 million square kilometers in the next few years.      Â   .   in urban land cover.

articles.title: Extreme Heat Is Exacerbating Air Pollution, a ‘Double Whammy' for Health
articles.summary: There is a bad air quality this summer due to extreme heat and climate change. Trump administration is trying to roll back various restrictions on air pollution. It is also encouraging more mining and burning of coal, the dirtiest of the fossil fuels. This month, the E.P.A. moved to a new location.

articles.title: Asia warming nearly twice as fast as rest of world
articles.summary: The continent's average temperature rose by 1.04 degrees Celsius above the 1991-2020 baseline. Last year was either the hottest or second-hottest on record for Asia. From 1991 to 2024, Asia's warming trend was almost double that of the 1961-1990 period. Sea-level rise on the Pacific and Indian Ocean sides surpassed global averages.

articles.title: Flood risk assessments outdated as population soars, NAO finds
articles.author: Mark Laurence Zammit
articles.summary: Audit of the National Audit Office (NAO) finds Malta's government's assessment on the risk of flooding as a result of climate change was outdated because it was based on 2011 population figures and ignored the 35% population rise since. NAO recommends that the government improve how it plans to prepare for the changing climate by creating detailed plans specific to different areas or industries.

articles.title: Alaska Heat Advisory: First Ever Warning Issued
articles.author: Alexandra Hartman
articles.summary: For the first time, Alaska has issued a heat advisory. Alaska is warming twice as fast as the global average, making it a focal point for climate change impacts. Average temperatures in Fairbanks have risen by 4 degrees Fahrenheit over the last 30 years. Alaskan wildfire season starts on April 1, a month earlier than before.

articles.title: This week's heat wave is up to 5 times more likely because of climate change
articles.summary: This week's heat wave in North Carolina has been reaching dangerous levels with the heat index as high as 110 degrees. The North Carolina Climate Science Report published in 2020 suggested this type of heat wave is becoming more common in the state due to climate change. Climate Central developed the Climate Shift Index to estimate how climate change has increased the likelihood of a particular daily temperature.

articles.title: Three ways climate change could impact education - with heat expected to cost children 'days' of class time
articles.author: Amber Allott
articles.summary: The Department for Education (DfE) has published a risk assessment report on climate change and its impact on England's schools. It says children could miss more than a week of learning each year to the heat in just a few decades. Many state-funded school buildings and sites already face a big flood risk, especially in secondary schools.

articles.title: 3 ways climate change could impact schools
articles.author: Education Writer
articles.summary: A new government risk assessment on climate change impacts on schools has been published. Children could lose more than a week of learning each year to the heat in just a few decades. Many state school buildings and sites already face a big flood risk, especially secondary schools. Almost 2 in 10 secondary schools in England are at high risk of flooding each year.

articles.title: How electric companies can reduce liability risks from climate change
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Asia is warming twice as fast as the rest of the world: WMO
articles.author: India Blooms News Service
articles.summary: Asia is warming twice as fast as the global average, according to the World Meteorological Organization's report. Extreme weather is already exacting an unacceptably high toll on lives and livelihoods. The only way to adapt to these polar weather patterns is to install more comprehensive early warning systems and capacity building measures.

articles.title: Severe Cold Front to Hit South Africa: Authorities Urge Public to Brace for Impact
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: South Africa is bracing for a powerful cold front set to strike the country's southwestern and interior regions from Wednesday, 25 June to Friday, 27 June. The weather system is expected to deliver heavy rain, snowfall, gale-force winds, and treacherous sea conditions. It is also expected to cause widespread disruption across multiple sectors, including transport, agriculture, and maritime operations. The government has called for preparedness and preparedness.

articles.title: Climate Change Deniers Are Switching Tactics
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Climate misinformation has shifted focus away from denying that climate change is happening and towards casting doubt on proposed solutions to it. It's aimed at discrediting proposed solutions, rather than denying it is happening at all. It is trying to cast doubt on the existence of climate change.

articles.title: Experts stress joint action for future climate adaptation strategy
articles.author: NEWS WIRE
articles.summary: Experts at a provincial conference on climate change and disaster resilience called for action to institutionalize climate-smart practices and mainstream disaster risk reduction into development planning. The conference was organized in collaboration with consortium partners Welthungerhilfe (WHH), Fast Rural Development Programme (FRDP), the Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) Sindh, and academic institutions here on Monday.

articles.title: If climate change is coming for Britain, why can't we get air conditioning?
articles.author: Matthew Lynn
articles.summary: Temperatures are forecast to hit 32 degrees in London over the weekend. It is June, and the UK is often hot at the start of summer. Only 5% of British homes come with built in cooling systems. In sunny Florida, 95% of new homes have air conditioning as standard.

articles.title: Mauritania pushes for sustainable fishing with EU support
articles.author: Denis Loctier
articles.summary: Mauritania has one of the world's richest fishing grounds. The fishing industry supports as many as 300,000 jobs and a quarter of government revenue. Environmentalists and scientists warn that many fish species are being harvested beyond sustainable limits, with some stocks in alarming decline. Fishermen in Nouadhibou, Mauritania are increasingly anxious, as once-abundant fish are now harder to find, forcing small boats to venture farther, using more fuel and taking greater risks. Some of these ships supply Mauritania's booming fishmeal industry.

articles.title: Heatwave Intensifies in Kashmir, Srinagar Records 35.5°C
articles.author: KL News Network
articles.summary: Srinagar recorded a maximum temperature of 35.5°C on Monday, which was 6.3°C above the seasonal average. Pahalgam recorded 30.6°C, 5.8°C higher than normal, Kupwara 34.7°C and Kokernag 33.2°C (6.0°C warmer than normal), and Gulmarg 26.0 °C above normal. Jammu recorded 34.1 °C, 3.5 °C below normal.

articles.title: Monsoon in waiting: Karachi's test for resilience
articles.author: Beena Khan
articles.summary: The 2020 monsoon season saw Karachi flooded with rainwater. The main reason for unprecedented rainfall is the effects of climate change. Sindh government has undertaken the task of restoring some semblance of normalcy in the city that was submerged by water. Storm Water Drain Project began in September 2022. 74 km of new drains have been constructed.

articles.title: Ensuing Humans And Animals' Conflicts Caused By Climate Change
articles.author: Odimegwu Onwumere
articles.summary: There are serious repercussions for Nigeria's animal population from climate change. The majority of Nigerian species are experiencing changes in their geographic distribution due to rising temperatures and changed precipitation patterns. Heat stress is especially harmful to livestock such as goats, sheep, and cattle. The spread of parasites and disease among livestock is facilitated by warmer temperatures and altered rainfall patterns. The UN is addressing the climate crisis and its effects in Nigeria on all fronts.

articles.title: Global Climate Policy Must Take Local Politics Into Account
articles.author: Ken Opalo
articles.summary: Low-income countries are most exposed to the consequences of climate change. They are often seen as the primary beneficiaries of global accords like the Paris Agreement and EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM). They rely on donors for funding and lack access to climate-related research and policymaking. Anchoring climate policy in the domestic politics helps to arrive at policies that balance the need to mitigate climate change with economic development.

articles.title: Scientists discover evidence of extensive human fire use 50,000 years ago
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Scientists have uncovered evidence that humans extensively used fire to transform environments as early as 50,000 years ago. This is far earlier than previously thought. An international team suggests that we may need to rethink the baseline of human-environment interactions in Earth's history.

articles.title: How to stay cool in a heat wave—even without air conditioning
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Climate change has been exacerbating heat waves, and the problem isn't going away, as it's been shown by the World Health Organisation (WHO) WHO says that climate change is to blame for the current heat waves. WHO says it's not going to get better.

articles.title: Letter: To examine the issue of human-induced climate change, consider why scientists believe it
articles.author: Inversion Therapy
articles.summary: Sen. Mike Lee calls climate change the 'green new scam'. He recommends reading 'The Scientific Guide to Global Warming Skepticism'. It provides a summary of the lines of evidence that have led 200 science academies throughout the world to conclude that climate change is human-caused. Satellites detect less heat escaping the top of the atmosphere, and surface observations measure more heat being returned to the earth.

articles.title: Carter County plans to keep the same property tax rate, despite hurricane disaster
articles.summary: Carter County Commission has no plans to increase the property tax rate as a result of Hurricane Helene, but the county sustained a financial blow as a consequence of the disaster. The county suffered a lot of damage from Helene's winds and rains, but there's no increase in property taxes.

articles.title: Heat warning persists in Toronto a day after record-breaking temperatures. Here's how hot it got
articles.author: Elissa Mendes
articles.summary: Monday was the hottest June 23 on record in Toronto. The temperature reached 36 degrees C. Environment Canada confirms it was the highest June 23 since records began in 1867. The June 23 was also the warmest June 23 ever recorded in Toronto, according to Environment Canada.

articles.title: It's not just the Global South. The climate crisis is already having a deadly impact in the UK.
articles.author: James Wright
articles.summary: Almost 600 people died in the heatwave in England and Wales between 19 June and 22 June due to climate change. People of any age are at risk because of the heat, but the vast majority of deaths predicted are those over 65. Last year, 1,311 people died because of heat in England. Europe faces a 40% drop in food production this century unless we change course.

articles.title: ‘Travel chaos': International flights impacted by war in Middle East
articles.summary: Rita Panahi discusses how international travel is being impacted by the war in the Middle East. Australians have been warned there may be travel chaos in the peak season due to the Iran-Israel conflict. Flights from Australia to the Mideast may be delayed and cancelled.

articles.title: Another heatwave could be on the way as weekend temperatures forecast to hit 30C
articles.author: Jordan Reynolds
articles.summary: It could reach the 30s in the far South East of England, but it's uncertain. It could be a short-lived localised heatwave in the South East. It's quite a long way away, but there is potential for it to reach that level.

articles.title: Why climate change is making severe turbulence on flights more likely
articles.author: Milton Speer
articles.summary: Unexpected severe turbulence injured crew and passengers on a Qantas Boeing 737 during descent at Brisbane on May 4, 2024. Global warming is increasing the frequency and intensity of wind gusts from thunderstorm 'downbursts' with serious consequences for air travel. Increased heat and moisture over eastern Australia are the key ingredients. Small planes with 4-50 seats are more vulnerable to microbursts.

articles.title: ‘This is a fight for life': climate expert on tipping points, doomerism and using wealth as a shield
articles.author: Jonathan Watts
articles.summary: Genevieve Guenther is an American climate communications specialist and author of The Language of Climate Politics: Fossil Fuel Propaganda and How to Fight It. Her book is written for people who are already concerned about the climate crisis and are willing to entertain a level of anxiety about it.

articles.title: Cecil eligible for USDA disaster drought loans
articles.author: Jane Bellmyer Cecil Whig
articles.summary: Washington, Frederick and Harford counties are being considered natural disaster areas due to weeks-long drought conditions. Local farmers have access to emergency loans to help with recovery efforts. Conditions range from D1 (Moderate Drought to D3 (Extreme Drought) classifications stretching back to December 2024.

articles.title: Staycationers will soon holiday abroad to escape the extreme heat at home
articles.author: Thea Coates Finance Reporter
articles.summary: The UK has had its hottest week on record. Many British travellers are already changing their holiday plans. Many are shifting their travel dates from summer to autumn and spring, or rethinking where they'll go. Spain is most commonly seen as becoming too hot for a summer break in the years ahead, followed by Greece, Turkey, Cyprus and Italy. Iceland, Canada and Sweden are climbing the list of preferred destinations for cooler climes.

articles.title: Water shortages loom as drought approaches record year of 1976
articles.author: Gordon Darroch
articles.summary: The Netherlands is experiencing one of its worst droughts since records began after another week with almost no rain and high temperatures. The official rainfall shortage increased by 32mm in the last week to 162mm, almost level with the record dry summer of 1976. The target water levels in the IJsselmeer and Markermeer have been raised as a precaution, but there is no risk to household supplies.

articles.title: Richmond's summer nights are getting hotter
articles.author: Karri Peifer
articles.summary: Richmond's average summer nighttime temperatures increased by 3.7°F between 1970 and 2024. In 96% of 241 locations analyzed by Climate Central, average summer temperatures at night increased in 96%. Reno, Las Vegas, El Paso, Texas, and Salt Lake City saw the biggest increases.

articles.title: How to stay cool and safe in a heat wave
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Climate change has been exacerbating heat waves. There are no federal heat rules to protect workers in the United States. If you don't have air conditioning, find public places that have it, such as movie theaters, malls and libraries. Some communities set up cooling centers.

articles.title: More than 500 bird species face EXTINCTION in the next 100 years thanks to climate change, scientists warn
articles.author: XANTHA LEATHAM
articles.summary: Climate change and habitat loss could cause more than 500 bird species to disappear in the next century. About 250 species could die out even with protection from human-caused threats. Large-bodied birds are more vulnerable to hunting and climate change, while birds with broad wings suffer more from habitat loss. Balearic shearwater, Atlantic puffin, sociable lapwing and yellow-breasted bunting are at risk of extinction.

articles.title: Most young people think Australia is a racist country, survey finds
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Australia's only national survey tracking reconciliation has released new data showing an almost 40 per cent increase in racism during the past decade. The data was released by the Reconciliation Research Institute of Australia (CRIA) on Wednesday. CRIA is the only national study tracking reconciliation.

articles.title: Bad news for nervous fliers! Severe turbulence is set to get even WORSE thanks to climate change, scientists say - as they discover a link between 'freak wind gusts' and global warming
articles.author: SHIVALI BEST
articles.summary: Professor Lance M Leslie and Milton Speer from the University of Technology Sydney used machine learning to identify the climate drivers behind 'downbursts' caused by extreme wind gusts. Global warming increases the amount of water vapour in the lower atmosphere, which fuels stronger thunderstorms. Small planes with 4-50 seats are more vulnerable to microbursts.

articles.title: Families urged to take action if they see sparrows in garden
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: House Sparrows are one of the most commonly spotted birds in UK gardens and outdoor spaces. The breeding numbers of house sparrows have "drastically declined" since records began and they are on the UK Red List for "high conservation concern". The RSPB is asking gardeners to let a patch of their garden grow wild this summer in order to encourage the insects which these birds need to live on.

articles.title: A Nation On The Brink: Climate Injustice And The Future Of Pakistan
articles.author: Furqan Ali
articles.summary: Pakistan's annual mean temperature has increased by 0.63°C in the last century. Jacobabad recorded a temperature of 60°C recently, Dadu and Sibbi followed close behind at 59.7°C and 56.6°C. Pakistan's total CO2 emissions stand at 0.53 gigatonnes per capita, placing it 16th globally per capita.

articles.title: Asia warming twice as fast as global average, WMO report warns
articles.author: Maleeha Zahid
articles.summary: Asia is warming twice as fast as the global average, according to the World Meteorological Organization's report. The report highlights increasing heatwaves, heavy rains, droughts, and rapidly melting glaciers affecting millions. It also highlights glacier shrinkage as a growing threat in the Central Himalayas and Tian Shan mountains.

articles.title: Sahara Heatwave: Summer Over? Extreme Temperatures Ahead?
